content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a single section of tissue, likely from a colorectal resection. On the left, there is a large, densely cellular, basophilic (purple) area representing an infiltrative tumor. On the right, there is pale, paucicellular tissue with large empty spaces, characteristic of pericolic/perirectal adipose (fat) tissue. The tumor shows an irregular, invasive border with the fat, suggesting it has grown through the bowel wall. I do not see any definite lymph nodes in this low-power view; the focus appears to be on the primary tumor and its extent of invasion.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is strategically placed at the deep invasive front of the tumor, which is the most informative area for assessing prognosis and staging. I would zoom into this specific location to: 
1. Evaluate the tumor's histologic grade by examining the degree of gland formation and cellular atypia.
2. Assess for adverse prognostic features that are best seen at the invasive margin, such as tumor budding (small clusters of cancer cells) and the nature of the inflammatory response.
3. Search for lymphovascular and perineural invasion, which are critical factors for determining the risk of metastasis.
4. Confirm the depth of invasion into the surrounding soft tissue, which is essential for T staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. I see irregular, complex, and cribriform (sieve-like) glands infiltrating a desmoplastic stroma (dense fibrous tissue). The malignant cells lining these glands show significant nuclear pleomorphism (variation in size and shape), hyperchromasia (darkly stained nuclei), and loss of normal cellular polarity. There are also some small, detached nests of tumor cells within the stroma, which are highly suspicious for tumor budding. My impression is of an aggressive colorectal adenocarcinoma, and I would carefully continue to scan this invasive front for definitive vascular invasion and to quantify the tumor budding.
